div.p:
- I am glad that Mr. Hall's commis
sion commission gave me the pleasure of
hearing from you and of your
welfare and kind remembrance
of all this family.

Petrarch's original inkstand
is not at Edgeworths town -- But
we have a copy of it, made from
a cast, made from a sketch or
drawing of the original inkstand
of Petrarchs which Lady Jersey saw
at Vaucluse when she was there
in what year of our Lady I know not
- Lady Jersey gave a sketch of her
drawing to Lady Lansdowne; and
when I was at Bowood in 1818
I saw that sketch in Lady L's portfo
lio portfolio & asked permission to take a
tracing of it. From my tracing
I had a model made at
Birming
ham Birmingham
- And from the cast had
5 or 6 Inkstands made in bronze
-- (very pretty they were -- only that the
stupid workman did not comprehend
that Cupids hands were joined in suppli
cation supplication & pointing to Heaven in attitude
of prayer and he made the bronze
hands closed and separated as if Cupid
was going to box -- I think La Martine
says that Lord Byron "fait boxer
les Manes" -- but Cupid never was
before represented as condescending
to such vulgar warfare --

I gave one of the inkstands I had
made in bronze, to each of my sisters
and one to Lady Lansdowne if I
rightly recollect and one I am sure
to Sir Walter Scott, who with his wonted
kind politeness had that inkstand
represented in one of his pictures on
the writing table before him -- I
cannot find the engraving tho I
know I have it somewhere -- I think
it is in some annual -- representing
the interior of Sir Walter Scotts study
- on second thoughts I am not
sure that in this Interior Sir Walter
Scott himself is - But probably you
& Mr. Hall know the engraving
You comprehend I trust from
the tracing enclosed that Cupid
lurches upon the cover of the inkstand
which fits over the hands which ought to be
pretty nondescripts - but unluckily
turned out ugly vulgar heads in this
tracing - The tracing was made for
you from my old sketch, this morning
by Francis (my brother) oldest boy
commonly called my nephew Torly
E who hopes you will accept of
it with his best wishes that you
may like it as the best he can do
at present - He will draw well
enough by & by as he is persevering
But he has so many other things to
learn before and after he goes to
school being no 10 years old that
his parents cannot allow him much
time for drawing of whh he is very fond

I wish you had mentioned your
little girl who interested me both
by what I saw and what I heard
from you of her - Messrs .
Marshal Marshall
&, I forget who the gentn. who possess
the copyright of my books inform
me that in consequence of numerous
requests to have my stories for
children & popular tales published
cheaply & in separate vols. volumes or parts
they are about to do so at last

Better late than never - Having
parted with the copyright I have no
private or pecuniary interest whatever
in these books and the publishers
only consult me out of civility and
to know in what manner & size I
should approve -- I have said
Print all Early Lessons in one & the
same size And Parents Assistant
in another larger size -- And Moral>
Tales and Popular may go in the
same size with all the other later or
Novels whichever they shd
should be called
Belinda Patronage Vivian Ennui or

I do not know why I bore you with
this - But I mean at the end of your
being bored to tell you that if your
little girl would like to have
Early Lessons in this new but I fear
it will not be elegant form, I will
send them to you for her -- How
very poor and shabby an offering
in return for the beautiful &
valuable books you & Mr. Hall
have given me - But it is no attempt
at return, simply intended as
a proof of kind remembrance to your
interesting little girl --

If I have time before the Post goes
out I will copy on the sketch of
Petrarchs Inkstand all that I have
here told you that Mr. Hall may have
it for himself with my assurances of
of being glad to do any thing to
oblige him even in such a
trifle -
I am very sorry to tell you that I
have lost (I believe by lending it)
the number of your work on Ireland
in which was your most kind and
gratifying account of Edgeworths Town

I have looked over the 1t & 2d
vols
volumes
bound
again & again & again & cannot
find it - I had a few unbound
numbers and concieving conceiving that there
were duplicates of the bound Vols. Volumes I
gave these generously to my sister -
Harriet Butler - It is possible this num-
ber number might be amongst those.- But in short
if you can send me that number whh
which
has so much of your kindness to us
in it I shall be particularly obliged

The little Mary for whom you are
so good to inquire is now quite well
and really a very good nice little
girl and for her age a wonderful
worker in worsted - There are now 6
of these Spanish eyed children - all
with warm affections and quick
but we trust not precocious intellects

Their father & mother most judicious
ly judiciously & unfashionably take care neither
to overwork their young brains they do not
to bring them forward either by
emulation or vanity and I am
sure that they will be all the better
and the happier for this moral
education.

You say you have much to
say to me - I must beg of you to say
it by letter then - for I have it not
in my power to come to London
at present - nor can I tell when
I may. Reasons too numerous
to mention - But not my own
ill health - for I am now really
well and as strong as at my age
any reasonable body can expect to
be -

My brother Francis has been
afflicted with some disease in
one of his eyes - which I know not
how to describe - double vision
occurs in one eye - and his medical
advisors insist upon rest - absolute
refraining from reading and writing

This is a dreadful privation to him
- borne with a degree of fortitude
& sweetness of temper which endear
him to all of us inexpressibly
- We are told that two years or there-
abouts thereabouts must elapse before he can
expect restoration of his eyesight
- - His having for the sake of
his family and tenantry acquired
the tastes & occupations out of doors
of a country gentleman & the
fulfilling the duties of Landlord agent
and magistrate now are the
resources & supports to his body &
mind & to health & happiness
so inseparably connected

He has been draining land
with success - But now we
are all intent upon potatoes -
and grinding - and drying drying and grinding -
and turning into starch &
laying up stores of oats & corn
as the present price to provide
against the dearth which is
much to be feared next year

In the meantime time I hope
we shall not be murdered & that
the horrible system of assassination
which prevails in Tipperary will
not spread like the disease in the
potatoes

It is not Catholic against
Protestant - But those who have
nothing & who are ill disposed
against all who have land -

I say those who have nothing
and who are ill disposed - Because
the assassinations & outrages are
not the consequence of want
or the desperation of distressed
tenants - on the contrary -

But I must stop for your
sake - and my own -
div.closer:
I am my dear Mrs. Hall
Yours sincerely
Maria Edgeworth -

postscript.p:
I rejoice to know that your Works
succeed in every way to your
satisfaction - But I wish you
would tell me more of this your
own self - I have seen Mr W Howds
lately who told me interesting particu
lars particulars of poor L E L - But confirming I
fear beyond doubt the fact that I wished not to believe
